overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students use a map on a coordinate plane to investigate distance. They calculate the distance between two locations by drawing a right triangle with vertical and horizontal legs and the hypotenuse joining the two sites. Students count blocks or use ordered pairs to write and evaluate expressions for the lengths of legs a and b and then apply the Pythagorean Theorem to solve for c, the distance.

overview_item_data_items: I can use the Pythagorean Theorem to determine the distance between two points in a coordinate plane.
I can use square roots to represent solutions to equations.
To calculate the distance between two points vertically aligned on the coordinate plane, identify their coordinate pairs and subtract the y-values.
To calculate the distance between two points horizontally aligned on the coordinate plane, identify their coordinate pairs and subtract the x-values.

To calculate the distance between two points on the coordinate plane that are not vertically or horizontally aligned, construct a right triangle, using the segment connecting the two points as the hypotenuse. Then, apply the Pythagorean Theorem.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students consider a graph and describe the distance between locations.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Right Triangles on the Coordinate Plane
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students graph points and use the Pythagorean Theorem to determine the distance between them on a coordinate plane.
Students calculate the length of a side of a triangle graphed on the coordinate plane.
